!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! P O S T   F U N D I N G   N O T E !!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
The Tiletto Kickstarter project has ended successfully by reaching its funding goal!
But, the Tiletto product is just beginning :-)
Want a Tiletto for yourself, family, or friends?
When this website is ready, you'll be able to do just that:
www.tiletto.com
Or, send me a message to discuss your needs (Click-through "Contact me" next to my picture).
Thanks to all that made the project a success :-)
We're forever grateful!
Best,
:-)
!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
Thank You and Welcome!
Thank you for visiting the Tiletto project page.
We hope you decide to pledge, which you can do at any time on the right-hand side. 
And, if you do, a sincere thank you! 
Function
Opens letters / envelops and does light work around the office such as opening boxes, removing staples and other static fasteners, and dealing with the occasional nut or bolt that gets in your way!
Small or large, envelopes, mailers, etc. are no match for Tiletto!
Tiletto makes quick work of opening boxes too.
At either end and in between, Tiletto helps you open things. As shown, from back to front, flat-head-screw-driver-like tool, hex wrenches (see sizes below), 1/4" hex driver, and a phillips-head-screw-driver-like tool.
Other Functions
Tiletto can help you do other things as well:
The chamfered sides of Tiletto can act as straight edges to help you draw lines, score lines, cleanly tear pieces of paper, etc. 
Both ends of Tiletto, which have different shapes / characteristics can be used as a pry bar to take care of a variety of odd jobs, where leverage is needed.
Although you probably don't use screw-pin anchor shackles in rigging your desk :-) you sailors out there can probably see that the centerline "needle hole" cutout can be used as a shackle key.
Come to think of it, you could probably use Tiletto as a fid on larger-diameter rope, but only if you practice knot craft at your desk!
In a pinch, can be used to stir coffee, LOL!
. . . and so on.  In short, Tiletto is a useful tool to have on, in, or around your desk!
Form and Finish
When it’s not working, Tiletto looks good laying in repose, hanging loose, or leaning confidently within arms reach, on or around your desk.
Tiletto -- in repose, but ready to help you get it done!
Tiletto, hanging around, taking it all in, while waiting for its next assignment.
Tiletto is ready when you are. As shown, along with some Kickstarter-reward friends!
Finish: Your Tiletto will come with a "stonewashed" finish -- literally washed for hours in a bath of proprietary alchemic "elixir" along with secret stone-like material in custom-made "tumblers" :-)
There are Two (2) Versions of the Tiletto:
1. Inch-Calibrated Hex-Wrench Version
2. Millimeter-Calibrated Hex-Wrench Version
Inch / millimeter sizes, starting from the back of the Tiletto, from the largest to the smallest hex-wrench opening:
Inch-Calibrated Version: 9/16", 1/2", 7/16", 5/16", and a 1/4 inch hex-bit driver in the center.
Millimeter-Calibrated Version: 13mm, 12mm, 10mm, 8mm, and a 1/4 inch hex-bit driver in the center.
Design Esthetic, Inspiration, and Perspiration (Prototyping!)
The sleek shape of Tiletto is inspired by the (1) “wasp waist” design pattern, which gives you a nice spot to place your hand (stylized cutouts on Tiletto's sides), when opening letters / envelops, and (2) the elongated shape of a needle hole, which provides a place for your thumb (hex and centerline cutouts), when using one end or the other to open boxes or deal with fasteners of various types.
We doo-noodled (doodling plus noodling = doo-noodling :-) on paper, then moved to CAD, and finally spun up the machines and cut prototypes for evaluation and testing.
A couple of the prototypes (bottom two) made during the intensive design process, showing the evolution of the "wasp waist" and "needle hole" thematic design elements into the current stylized version embodied by your Tiletto.
In addition to the chamfered sides of the Tiletto (see cover shot at top of project page), the "flat-head" like screw driver on back is milled at an angle as well. These precise design features enable some of Tiletto's key functionality. Photo - M. Bond
Material
Titanium, but of course!
Ti-6Al-4V, otherwise known as "Grade 5" or "G5" for short.
“Half the weight and twice as strong as steel.”
Dimensions
Approximately 7 inches ( 178 mm) long by 1 inch ( 25 mm) wide, at its widest, and 1/16 inch ( 1.6 mm) thick.
(More than double the thickness of a TacTiClip, if you have one -- "World's strongest Multi-Use Clip" -- had to get a plug in here at least once  :-)
Rewards
Keeping it fairly simple for now, pledge for one (1) of six (6) reward tiers on the right:
One (1) Tiletto with inch-calibrated hex-wrench cutouts.
One (1) Tiletto with millimeter-calibrated hex-wrench cutouts.
Set of Two Tilettos (2), one each of the inch- and millimeter-calibrated hex-wrench versions.
Early Bird: Get 'em while you can!  Any of the rewards above, which are limited by number.
Tiletto is a great Kickstarter reward to complement your collection -- you're in good company with Tiletto!
Stretch Goals 
NOTICE: Team Tiletto may add, change, and / or delete stretch goals at any time before each stretch goal is reached, based on changing circumstances.
Obviously, the team will do it's level best to give Backers as much notice as possible of any changes before reaching each stretch goal.  
$18,000 Stretch Goal: That said, let’s first all stretch for A N N O D I Z I N G, which will be triggered, if we meet this stretch goal.
(Add-on cost for anodizing to be determined later as we get closer to this stretch goal.) 
Here's a couple of examples of anodized Tilettos.
Color treatments "Gonzetto" (blue-bronze) on the left, "Stonetto" (natural titanium, "stonewashed") in the middle, and "Bronzetto" (bronze-only) on the right. Photo taken with indirect sunlight, around 5:00 PM.
 *
Same three showing reflectivity of anodizing at the tips of the Tilettos. Picture taken with indirect sunlight, around 5:00 PM.
Team
It's not just me (or about me :-)
You may know Mike Bond of Ti2 Design, creator of five (5) successful Kickstarter projects: Ti2 Para-Biner, Ti2 Sentinel X -- Aluminum Cache, Ti2 Sentinel -- Titanium Cache, Ti2 Pen, and TORQ Bottle Opener!
Both being Kickers, and on the island of Oahu, it's was easy to meet up and collaborate on each other's projects.
Ti2 Design is our go-to company for all things related to Design For Manufacturing (DFM), helping to turn Tilleto from "thought to thing."
Another valuable member of the team, who you may know as well, is Brad Martin of Tactical Keychains, creator of four (4), soon to be five (5), successful Kickstarter projects: Bottle Grenade, WTF - Mini Titanium Keychain, TiKey, TiPen, and the latest, Titanium Bottle Grenade 2.0, funding now!
We started our first respective projects around the same time, and had a "one helluva" ride our first time out, which Brad can tell you about, if you buy him a beer :-) he needs it to relive / retell the story, LOL!
Tactical Keychains is our go-to company for all things anodizing, should we reach our 18k Stretch Goal!  Brad is also, like Mike, a great friend, always willing to lend a helping hand!
Our most recent virtual team member is Phillip Kauffman, who deserves a round of applause, and a big cheer, for the successful funding of his first Kickstarter project, the Screw Grabber!
Phillip and i reached out to help each other's projects from a suggestion made by one of our Backers!
It was touch and go, but the Screw Grabber made it, with everyone pitching in!  Definitely, a Kickstarter community success story!
Along the way, Phillip found the time, in between full-on marketing, to enhance the Tiletto cover picture with a great graphic design, which was very thoughtful and greatly appreciated.  If you visit the Screw Grabber, you can see more of Phillip's great graphic design skills.
Phillip has kindly offered to support our project with any additional graphic design work we may need, and potentially collaborating on future projects.
Once again, congratulations Phillip, and a big Thank You!
As we add additional team members from the Kickstarter community, we'll feature them here.
It takes a great team to conceive, create, and bring to closure products worthy of being called a reward!
Funding, Production, and Fulfillment Schedule
In weeks, starting from the first week of April 2014:
Week 1: Project funding period ends, funding goal achieved, and initiation of funds transfer process.
Week 2 Funds - Funds transferred to Team Tiletto.
Week 3 - Tiletto cuts checks for raw titanium sheet stock, manufacturing supplies, and reserving machine time.
Week 4 - Titanium sheet stock and manufacturing supplies secured and manufacturing schedule planned for Reward Tier 1.
Weeks 5-6 - Manufacturing cycle for Reward Tier 1 complete, along with QA / QC.
Week 7 - Finishing and fulfillment for Reward Tier 1 completes.
Weeks 8 - 12 Manufacturing through fulfillment process completed for Reward Tier 2.
Weeks 12 - 16 Manufacturing through fulfillment process completed for Reward Tier 3 and project concludes successfully.
This production schedule allows for any number of glitches and gremlins to pop up and be ground under foot along the way to fulfilling Backer rewards!
Final Tiletto prototype getting ready to be milled.
Design Changes
We're allowing for design changes to Tiletto during the project based on Backer feedback and our own judgement based on the multiple tradeoffs between function, form, marketability, and DFM, not to mention Kickstarter product design guidelines.  In a word, we value your input! 
Project Communications 
Please, talk amongst yourselves, LOL :-)
But seriously, will respond to comments and messages within 24 hours, which will enable scheduling our time efficiently, in a sincere effort, as always, to be as responsive as possible to your questions and concerns.
Additionally, we will update Backers once every two (2) weeks to formally keep Backers apprised of status.
Finally, all suggestions for changes to Tiletto's design are very much welcomed and are appreciated; however, for obvious reasons, we'll be unable to "go back to the drawing board" multiple times.  For this reason, team Tiletto will not engage in substantive dialog about Tiletto's design, but will simply accept all suggestions -- with much gratitude -- for mindful consideration.
Important Note to International Backers!
You are responsible to check your country's customs requirements regarding the importation of your reward as described above.
Use of Proceeds
WIth your help, (1) procure all the material and services to fulfill your pledges and (2) help to continue establishing a commercial infrastructure to support an on-going concern, both of which includes products and services related to the following:
Raw titanium sheet stock.
Various machines to manufacture and finish Tiletto (and other products for future projects).
Manufacturing and finishing supplies.
Quality Assurance and Control activities.
All the other managerial and administrative stuff needed to get 'er done and in your hands.
Packaging and labeling machines, tools, and supplies.
Postage.
International shipping requirements.
Intellectual Property.
Web-based platform and pulg-ins, including shopping cart technology and consulting for same.
Product design software and consulting for same.
. . . and the list goes on
In short, we need your help to make Tiletto -- and more -- happen!
Thanks again and look forward to sending you a reward!
We're out of the gate, headed towards turn one, and hoping you decide to run with us :-)
Best,
Team Tiletto :-)
Track Tiletto's Progress
Click through image just above to see Tiletto project progress.
A final pic before you pledge :-) Tiletto with some more Kickstarter-reward friends!

What Are StickQuik™ Bands?
StickQuik™ Bands are a Patent-Pending, next generation accessory that offer the user handy access, organization and storage for tools, utensils or implements of any kind.
These can be used in your cabinets or medicine cabinets!
Dishwasher Safe
StickQuik™ Bands are a band of elastic silicone that can be stretched to snugly fit any ferrous or non-ferrous tool or tool handle. StickQuik™ Bands come in two sizes, 0.50” (1/2") and 0.375” (3/8"), to accommodate most sizes of tools, utensils and implements. StickQuik™ Bands are made of high consistency grade silicone that is embedded with neodymium magnets.
Silicone was chosen for its durability and elasticity, unlike crude rubber used in elastic bands. Plus, silicone is a non-allergic and non-toxic material that is safe to use around food. Neodymium magnets were chosen, as these rare earth magnets are the strongest permanent magnets available.
Very handy when you're working underneath your car.
Uses/Function:
StickQuik™ Bands can be used by professional and weekend mechanics, gardeners, RV enthusiasts, handy men/women, teachers, hobbyists, crafters, artists and anyone who cooks or uses any implement of any kind.
If you don’t have anything metal to have the bands stick to, some of the rewards will have the option to get the bands with 1” metal discs or 12” metal strips that have adhesive tape on the back, so you can stick them anywhere.
Great for tooth brushes
 For those with peg boards for their tools, we will offer the metal strips with pegs that fit peg boards.
How StickQuik™ Bands Began:  
We created StickQuik™ Bands because we wanted to use one for ourselves. We searched high and low for something like it and found nothing close to them in the market.
So, we thought that if we wanted something like this, then others would too. There are some magnetic tool organizers on the market that come in the form of magnetic strips, trays, bowls and bars for toolboxes or walls. These products only serve the function of storage and don’t address having a tool, utensil or implement handy as you work.
No need to set your tools on the ground
StickQuik™ Bands lets the user do both since it attaches to and stays with the tool. The two of us began work about 2 years ago. We thought up various ideas using different materials and magnets.
 We mocked up ideas into visual and working models to see what would work best. We researched many different magnets for size, strength and shapes.
Silicone was researched for its stretching properties and injection mold temperatures. After all this research we paired the right magnets with the right silicone.
When we felt we were ready for prototyping, we researched large silicone injection molding companies, domestic and abroad.
All of the companies responded that engineering a mold would be very difficult or impossible to pull off and bowed out. Undaunted, because we felt we had such a great product, we began looking locally for companies.
After a short search we found a company that has 30+ years experience molding rubber, plastics and silicone. At our first meeting, after showing models and drawings to them, they understood what we wanted and assured us that they could manufacture our product. They worked closely with us as we further refined the design.
After the refinements we went to a 3-D model and finalized it. We had a 2 cavity mold tooled for the prototypes.
From those two cavities, we made the fully functional StickQuik™ Bands that you see in this campaign.
Why kickstarter?
We are thrilled with Kickstarter! We love to see others who have great ideas that they want to bring to the public. We love the energy people put into their projects. We both feel this is the best model to launch a campaign for our simple yet useful product. The conventional retail model makes it hard for the “small guys” to get their great ideas into the market. Plus, we don’t have enough capital to launch StickQuik™ Bands on our own. This is where we need your help. The two of us have self-funded this project and have taken it as far as we can. The $27,000 goal is for funding final cavity tooling costs, raw materials and initial production costs, allowing us to meet our minimum order quantities.

June 2014

• Last week of the month, we pack and ship pledges to all our Kickstarter supporters!
July 2014

campaign.story:
Fyxation Bicycles: Cogly is a simple tool that let's clean your chainrings and cassette without having to use multiple brushes or rags to get into those hard to reach spaces. ... It's a very simple design but it looks extremely effective.
BikeRumor.com: "Inspired by the replaceable blade system found on your common hacksaw, the Cogly is a cleaning tool that allows you to easily slip a rag between your cogs."
IBikeDaily.com: "The Cogly Bike Tool will remove any unwanted grit and grime, keeping your drivetrain cleaner and increasing the life of your components."
Why do I need Cogly?
Keeping your bike's drivetrain cleaned and lubed will improve the longevity and ride quality of your bike more than anything else. You need to remove debris from the gears (especially the cassette, the rear set of gears). The problem is that existing methods are tedious, which is why it often simply doesn't get done.
Cogly allows you to use one hand to slip a cleaning rag between the gears, clear of the grimy parts, while the other hand rotates the pedals.
Who are you?
Gear Gear: a venture by three people that are passionate about cycling and want to build bicycle accessories to keep the activity simple and enjoyable.
Bob Schultz: The chief member, currently trying to avoid an official title. Several thousand dollars into this little project, he has learned a ton (among other things, that he has a very accommodating spouse).
Thom Dieterich: Chief marketing-type guy, and something of a passionate nerd in the bicycle and internet computing flavors.
Karen Schultz: Well, she puts up with the chief guy, and her next occupation (if all goes well with our campaign) is to handle logistics and keep Bob's head from getting too big. For now, let's call her Director of Operations.
How did you come up with the idea?
What follows is a brief history of grime. The names have been changed to protect the innocent, or at least until we have permission to reveal their true identity.
It was a warm summer day (No, really! It's not cold in Minnesota year round) and Bob felt the need to clean the gears on his road bike, specifically the cassette (the rear set of gears). A common way of doing this is to run a strip of rag between all the gears to remove the grime that has built up. Having done this many times, Bob was reminded what a pain it can be. Sure someone must have a tool that could hold a rag taut so that one hand could be used to clean the cogs and the other to rotate the pedals, Bob searched for an existing tool, but nothing. An idea was born.
August 2013
Bob collaborates with a friend (we'll call him "Pat") to get his ideas into drawings. "Pat" does a nice job. In fact, he solves the problem of attaching the strip of rag to the tool with a simple and effective idea: use a wing-nut.
First concepts of Cogly
September 2013
Bob meets with CAD engineer ("Tim") at a local coffee shop and a design emerges in the form of a CAD model:
October 2013
Bob finds a manufacturer in the Twin Cities area that specializes in prototypes to create the first ever Cogly in ABS plastic cut using CNC.
For those of you that care about such things, Bob is using the prototype on his road bike, built around an early model Cannondale Six13 frame.
Note the orientation of the bolts on the first prototype. Fine tuning the design, Bob requests another CAD drawing that turns the bolts 90 degrees so that a strip of rag secured flat against the pads will now have an edge that can go straight between the gears when the tool is held naturally.
After a patent search and subsequent provisional patent application by a patent firm (we'll refer to it as The Firm), the latest design is 3D printed.
New bolt pad design
This prototype provided a learning opportunity. Note the rough curve. It turns out you need to be careful when exporting a 3D model from one CAD file format to another.
The first in a series of quotes from manufacturers Cogly is collected.
November 2013
The Firm completes the filing of the provisional patent application. Cogly is now "patent pending."
There are a number of manufacturers near the Twin Cities, so second and third quotes to manufacture Cogly are collected. With reasonable quotes from nearby manufacturers, the costs of making Cogly a reality become clear.
Between quotes, the design of Cogly continues to evolve.
Bolt holes are made smaller and centered.
December 2013
We form a new company, Twin Cities Cycling Products LLC. The name is a mouthful, so we intend to conduct business as a DBA.
Another very good CAD engineer ("Rocky") helps Bob evolve the design even further, and the final prototype is produced in the actual plastic and color we expect Cogly to be manufactured with.
The label is "photoshopped" in using Gimp -- you can blame Bob.
January 2014 
We decide on a DBA for the business, "Gear Gear."
February 2014
We submit our campaign to Kickstarter. And here you are. Thank you for your support. We truly appreciate it.
Where do you plan on manufacturing it?
We've collected multiple quotes from manufactures around the Twin Cities (Minneapolis and St. Paul in Minnesota), and we plan on having it manufactured right here in the U.S., most likely in the Twin Cities.
Why Kickstarter?
We've already put in some of our own money, but we need help funding initial efforts to manufacture the Cogly tool and evaluate the consumer response to the product.
To make Cogly a real product, we need your help to have a mold built for the initial runs of the product, and to have packaging professionally designed and sourced.
When can I get my own Cogly?
If our Kickstarter project is successful, we'll be able to start the process of getting to production right away.
The first step will be getting the injection mold created and packaging sourced. This will take approximately two months to complete, but once it's created production will start right away.
Once we have product, packaging and shipping should only take another 2 weeks. Kickstarter backers who opt for the Earlybird levels will get their Cogly from from the initial production runs. Later, late May or early June, we'll then be able to take delivery of the rest of our order and get them shipped out to the rest of our backers.
Thank you for your support.

Hello, we are a small team of scientists, designers, and print production experts. 
We are tired of the dreary, low quality, unconsidered, and overpriced lab notebooks that are currently available for students and professionals in the lab. So we decided we would make our own, and we need your help to make them a reality!
The Series-E2 was designed based not only on our years of experience in the lab, but on extensive feedback from engineers and scientists in the field. 
It became apparent that current engineer notebooks are woefully inadequate in every parameter. Notably, lack of page numbers, flimsy see through paper, non-archival paper, flimsy board, low-end adhesive binding, pages that do not lay flat, binding that does not allow the book to lay open, no user data page, no index, and high cost. The Series-E2 addresses all of these parameters and more.
We began with refining the grid. It is the same 5x5 grid (0.2" spacing), but we have optimized it to be far less distracting and more consistent across pages. We then added page numbers, which we view as an essential asset of any lab notebook. 
Next, we added a more comprehensive and organized user data page to make labeling and archiving your notebook easier. Finally, we added an index with listed page numbers, making indexing easier and more organized.
User data page; user index (page 1 or 4)
The Series-E2 utilizes flat back smyth sewn binding, the highest quality binding that is commercially available. A slow and costly process, but one that yields unparalleled results.
This is the most durable type of binding, meaning pages will not fall out, the cover will not disconnect from the book block, therefore, you will not lose your work.   
This technique also allows for the most lay-flat property of any book. Even on the first pages the book will lay flat and stay open, so you can easily stay focused on your work.
After a few months of testing we found what we think is the perfect paper for lab work. Something that is a joy to write on and will not fall apart with extensive use.
The paper is substantially thicker, making it both more durable and higher opacity. The high opacity allows for very minimal ink bleed through with most pens. The paper is also acid-free so it will not deteriorate and yellow, as standard lab paper, after a few years. 
The cover board is considerably thicker than standard board, making the book much more sturdy. Furthermore, the cover has a special coating that protects the book from spills and general wear and tear. 
WE LISTEN: feedback is pivotal in the design of every notebook we produce.
Local Production: Not only does this support local fair-wage workers and their families, it allows for a higher level of quality control.
Low Cost & Functional: We develop notebooks that optimize both cost and functionality for our users.
Diligent Design: We spend months in the lab writing in a single notebook, this is why we believe it absolutely essential that our notebooks are not only functional but feel considered, inviting, and personable. 
Producing notebooks in this way is slow and costly.  But, we feel this level of quality and attention to detail is definitely worth it. Your support will help us complete this project, allow us to make these notebooks available to more people faster, and even reduce the cost of these notebooks. We truly appreciate your time and consideration. 
Thank you for reading, 
~VELA TEAM

campaign.story:
SORRY YOU MISSED OUR PROJECT! CLICK HERE TO GO TO OUR WEBSITE FOR MORE INFORMATION ABOUT THE INK.
_____________________________________________________
The Clicky Post- "For this pen, “unique” would be an understatement without question…"
Cool Material- "The pens are both lightweight and durable and worthy of the intelligent musings you’re scribbling down."
Ed Jelley- "The tank-like construction cuts down on all associated worries with damaging the pen by carrying it sans-case in my pocket."
From the Pen Cup- "The design of the pen’s clip is classic Karas— unique and stylish with just a hint of bad-ass."
Gear Hungry- "We haven’t owned a fountain pen since the shoddy one forced upon us in elementary school, but Karas Kustoms' latest might just make us step back and reconsider."
Gourmet Pens- "Karas Kustoms... have come out with the ultimate pen."
Pen Addict- "It's a great pen by great people and would make an excellent addition to any writing arsenal."
Well Appointed Desk- "The clip is an industrial strength, streamlined beauty that’s held on with signature Karas hex bolts that give the pen a nod to its industrial roots."
_____________________________________________________
Ink
We are happy to introduce our latest endeavor, a custom machined aluminum pen featuring custom metal grip sections and a completely redesigned clip. We call it "Ink".
Click here to see a separate slideshow
Philosophy
We wanted to create an heirloom quality, American designed and manufactured pen to help counteract the current trend of impersonal communication and disposable consumerism. Can a machined pen accomplish this goal? Maybe not, but it looks amazing while it tries.
Life is fast-paced and disposable. We rarely take time to slow down, put thoughts to paper, and share those ideas with others around us. Do we want to be remembered for email, or for a hand written note that has character and a feeling of sincerity?
Communication has become too impersonal. Everything is disposable. We aim to change that.
Versions
Ink can be either a fountain or rollerball pen, giving the user their own preferred writing experience. We completely designed Ink from scratch, using high quality parts and materials. The grip section of Ink comes in either aluminum, brass or copper. This gives Ink the look and feel of a high dollar, custom pen, but because we make the pen ourselves, we are able to offer it at a fraction of the price of other custom pens.
The fountain pen version of Ink features a #5,stainless steel, German made nib assembly and converter, Manufactured by Schmidt. The nib assembly works with international standard ink cartridges, or you can purchase bottled ink to use with the provided convertor. The colors available in bottled ink are almost limitless, so you aren't just limited to black, blue and red. And because you can refill your pen over and over, you are creating less waste than if you used regular, disposable pens.
The rollerball version uses an included capless rollerball refill, also manufactured by Schmidt (p8126, black, .6mm), that is guaranteed to not dry out, even if the cap is left off of the pen for a year. This refill offers an incredibly smooth writing experience and is currently used by several other manufacturers for this reason. You can also use a standard Parker ballpoint compatible refill, including the Fisher Space Pen refill, if you so choose.
Why Aluminum, Copper and Brass?
We chose these three different materials to use for the grip section of the Ink for several reasons. First, we wanted to be able to offer a different aesthetic for each pen and allowing the user to choose a color and a material means the pen will be very unique. Second, for the fountain pen version of the Ink, using copper and brass grip section will allow for using more caustic inks that can potentially harm aluminum if submerged for filling (using cartridges shouldn't make any difference). Third, by choosing the copper or brass grip section instead of the aluminum, one can change the weight distribution of the pen slightly for those who like a slightly heavier pen. And finally, we think the different options just look really, really cool and we have the capability to offer all three materials, so we did.
Stats
Because Ink is machined from T-6061 aircraft aluminum, then anodized, it is lightweight as well as durable. Traditionally, more expensive pens are made from plastics or hard rubber, and, while very beautiful, can break if handled roughly or accidentally dropped. Ink can be tossed into a bag or pocket without the fear of breakage. Even if accidentally dropped, your Ink may show a little mark or ding, but it will survive and will have a visual story to tell about its life.The clip and screws on Ink are stainless steel and are designed to last a lifetime.The stainless #5 nib (FH241 fine) is manufactured in Germany and is a quality, well made unit. The included converter is also made by Schmidt and it very high quality. Weight and dimensions for each version are listed below:
Ink Capped
Ink Fountain Pen- 1.4 ounces for aluminum grip section, 1.6 ounces for copper and brass, including converter (no ink).
Ink Rollerball Pen- 1.4 ounces for aluminum grip section, 1.7 ounces for copper and brass, including refill.
Why fountain pens?
Fountain pens work and feel differently than other pens. Ink flows onto the paper and lubricates the nib, allowing it to glide across the paper smoothly as you write. Only a light pressure is needed to put ink to paper, no pushing to get it to write like you do with ballpoint. This allows you to write in a clean and fluid manner, especially if you are writing in script (cursive). If you are pushing hard, you may damage the nib and your pen will not perform as it should.
Fountain pens are still a mystery to many folks, something they remember seeing in cartoons as a kid or something only old people used to use. We can assure you, they are very much still around and can be used everyday just like any other pen. The fine folks over at Goulet Pen Company have an excellent primer on fountain pens if you would like to learn more. They are helpful and very knowledgeable about all things fountain pen, so check them out (we are not associated with Goulet in any way, we just think they are awesome).
We realize that fountain pens may not be for everyone, which is why we are also offering a rollerball version of our pen. The .6mm capless rollerball refill included with the pen is extremely smooth and is one of the best that we have used.
Why Kickstarter?
Our new clip design requires a new manufacturing process we don't currently use in production. We can machine the parts for the pen bodies here in the shop, but we need to locally outsource some cutting and polishing to get the clips dialed in. By pledging toward our Ink project you can help us reach our financial goal so that we can afford to machine and purchase the parts we need to make the Ink a reality. Plus, by doing so, you get to own a really cool, American made pen.

That being said, if we become massively over-funded, our original estimated delivery dates will become pushed back to accommodate the larger production numbers. Anyone who pledges to our project can do so in confidence, as we have a history of delivering quality rewards to our backers.

updates.update_content: We have been hinting on social media about a new project and many of you asked to be notified when we launched, so here we go. We have collaborated with Mike Dudek (clickypost.com) and come up with our own version of a pen holder- The CUBE. Take a look.
Shipped!

Hello! We wanted to post a quick update just to let you know what's going on. We are on track to be shipping next week. We are doing the final packaging and setting up to ship all the pledge levels at once. Our polisher got behind and still owes us some finished clips, but that won't stop us from shipping next week as we already have almost all of the pens finished and ready to go. We will be boxing all of the rewards and shipping them out as a group on pallets, separating them into domestic and international. They will then be picked up, sorted, weighed and, finally, sent on their way. We know you have been waiting a long time and we appreciate your patience. We will post photos of the shipping process as soon as we have them so you can get a feel for the process.

Hello backers! It is a rainy week here in Mesa, Arizona. We are enjoying this wonderful weather and have started final assembly on the Ink! We are starting to receive all the colors back in batches from our anodizer and have started assembling the pens. All of the copper and brass parts have been tumble polished and packaged separately to keep them nice and shiny. The hand polished clips are being added to the pen caps and the bodies are being assembled, getting ready for final packaging.
We are pleased with the way the pens are turning out and we can't wait to get them into your hands. As soon as we have them assembled, we can hopefully start shipping. If the anodizer keeps the schedule they gave us, that may be the end of next week. We will keep you updated.

Happy Friday! We wanted to post an update before we left for the weekend so that everyone is up to speed with the project. We have been inspecting, tumbling and vibratory polishing all of the pens. The grip sections, bodies and caps have been deburred, inspected and are being put through two separate tumbling operations. This allows us to have a much more consistent surface finish compared to hand sanding or polishing. Here are some photos of some of the process:

As most of you know, we sent out shipping surveys last week. Nearly all of you have filled them out, and we thank you for that. A very small number of you still have not filled out your survey and we will be contacting you if we don't hear from you in the next few days. If you don't hear from us, that means you are good to go.
Just a quick update today as we are busy getting work done. Have a great week!

Production Schedule-
Hello backers! We have been pushing forward despite the setbacks and have been making excellent progress. The guys in the shop stepped up and are almost done with the fountain pen grip sections! We only have a bit of brass and the copper to go before we switch over to the rollerball grip sections next week. As soon as the aluminum rollerball grip sections are done, we will be doing a final inspection of all the aluminum parts then sending them off to the anodizer! The anodizer should have them from 7-10 days and we can start assembling and shipping after that. That puts right at the end of August if all goes according to plan. campaign.story:
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
WE ASKED 1000+ RETAILERS WHY THEY DON’T CARRY MORE DOMESTICALLY PRODUCED PRODUCTS. They all said the same thing: "Our customers don’t care about domestically produced products." We call bullsh*t, but we need your help to prove them wrong.
 Let's give American Manufacturing its own yellow ribbon... a wearable way to show your support for the war they're fighting daily.  
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
About the Bluelace itself: We asked one of America's very last shoelace manufacturers to produce the very best shoelace they'd ever made. 
Adding extra pressure to the pot, we promised them that if they could develop something truly impressive, it had the potential to become more than just a simple shoelace; it could become a symbol! 
And this symbol could do more than just help their business, it could help break the ongoing cycle of outsourcing, offshoring, and making things cheaper, faster and worse. It could help ALL American manufacturers. 
We said that if this shoelace was amazing enough, and we get it into enough shoes and tied to enough wrists, it would let retailers know that cost isn't the only thing driving their customers' buying habits, and that if they stocked the right domestically produced goods, their customers would be willing to give them a chance. 
THEY CAME BACK WITH A SHOELACE UNLIKE ANYTHING WE'D EVER SEEN: A triple-dense, double-waxed canvas lace, tipped in Aluminum. Could they be the everlasting gobstoppers of shoelaces? They're certainly light-years ahead of whatever cheap lace came pre-loaded in your imported sneakers. 
So how do we know THE BLUELACE is better? It's a good question. Truth be told, we weren't sure how to test 'em either. So we called our friend, American strongman Matt Mills and asked if he could put them through the ringer. We wanted to see if he could rip them like a phone book. He said he had a better idea though. 
With nothing but a single pair of BLUELACES linking his harness to a set of ultra-heavy duty tow straps, he was able to pull a 13,000 pound truck!
If they're strong enough to pull a 13,000 pound truck, they're probably tough enough for whatever you'll put them through... they just might be sturdy enough to pull us all together!
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Why lace up blue at all? 
Lacing up blue lets retailers know that you're willing to give a second look to domestically produced products. 
Lacing up blue lets American manufacturers -- the men and women fighting to innovate and bring better-built products to market at a time when their competitors undercut them by cutting corners abroad -- know you appreciate the war they're fighting daily. 
Equally important, whether worn in a sneaker, boot, or tied to a wrist, lacing up blue is fun, bright, bold and vibrant.
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Whether or not you decide to take the plunge and lace up blue, we'd love it if you kept the following in mind this holiday seasons:
According to printed reports, the United States has lost a staggering 32 percent of its manufacturing jobs since the year 2000.
According to the US Department of Commerce, every $1 spent on American made products fuels another $1.40 in spending elsewhere in the US economy. 
According to The Information Technology & Innovation Foundation, on average, 1,276 manufacturing jobs were lost every day for the past 12 years.
According to Diane Sawyer and ABC World News, if each of us spent just $64 on American made goods during our holiday shopping, the result would be 200,000 new jobs.
 For this particular project though, per $5 contribution…
$1 goes to Processing fees (10% of all money received is paid directly to New York City-based Kickstarter and Amazon for processing the transaction)
$2 goes directly to our shoelace factory in Portsmouth Ohio for manufacturing the laces using American materials and shipping them to our warehouse. 
$1 covers shipping, this includes the stamps purchased from USPS and the envelope bought in bulk from our Texas-based manufacturer.
$1 is paid to our Henderson, Nevada warehouse for packing each individual order (likely a set of BLUELACES plus whatever additional goodies we decide to throw in the pouch).
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------
Our stretch goals are all about helping to spread the word and telling OTHER American Manufacturer's stories.  
When Flint and Tinder first launched on Kickstarter a little more than a year ago, we found that what drove the success of our underwear project was a simple idea: For the first time in a very long time, by telling their story in the video below, we connected the buyers with the makers in a very powerful way. 
It was exciting stuff! And that connection ultimately helped us to keep 100 people employed and the factory doors open for far longer than anyone had forecasted. 
Now, with your support, we want to tell OTHER, amazing American manufacturing stories through video with the hope that we can make an even larger impact on their businesses...
Stories like the Fortune 500 CEO who gave it all up to revive a New England wool blanket factory. 
Stories like the American machine shop that used old-world gearing techniques that helped to land the Rover on Mars. 
Stories like the young, energetic team who bought a hat factory and are making the old cool using a mix of modern marketing and classic style. 
For the first 5,000 backers and every 10,000 there after, who lend a hand to make THE BLUELACE PROJECT a reality, we'll produce another video and distribute it direct to your inbox.
Know of an amazing American manufacturing story? Send us an email with your story idea(s) and if it's a story that fits the bill (and we have the # of backers to do it! ) we'll send our high-end video production team around the country to capture the best of best. 
-----------------------------------------------------------------------------

Our 10-Year Hoodie project taught us that making a great product in a bunch of colors and sizes can get pretty complicated. We've fulfilled nearly 100% the orders placed. More importantly, when it's all said and done, every single order to every single backer will have been shipped in the AUG - NOV timeframe that we promised.

Still, we learned a lot...

THE BLUELACE PROJECT centers on one product in one color. 

We don't anticipate any major obstacles for The Bluelace but we can say that should challenges arise, we will manage them efficiently and with you in mind. Still, we'd like to think that the backers invested in seeing this idea succeed, people who believe that it's high time AMERICAN MANUFACTURING GOT ITS OWN YELLOW RIBBON, will be less focussed on the product itself than what it represents and the message it sends.

Due to a grant becoming unavailable, the Commercial Drive Parklet requires more funding than its initial Kickstarter goal of $3500. In order to fully fund the parklet, we need to raise $8,000. Please help us reach our goal by spreading the message!
We received feedback that the project could do more to expand its impact into the community. In response, we have added new and improved stretch goals:
IF YOU HELP US RAISE $5000 - We will train five youth in the community on laser etching/cutting, and coordinate a painted street mural in the neighbourhood!
IF YOU HELP US RAISE $8000 - We will train ten youth in the community on laser etching/cutting, coordinate a painted street mural in the neighbourhood, and host a parklet launch block party!
The Commercial Drive Parklet is one of a few projects selected as part of VIVA Vancouver’s 2013 Parklet Pilot Program. Unlike other parklets led by large architecture and landscape architecture firms, this is the only one undertaken by active residents of the project neighbourhood. 
VIVA Vancouver maintains strict rules that all parklets be open to the public, and free of any logos or branding. Everyone is invited to use the space, and no one can be denied access!
This project represents one heck of a collaborative effort! 
Steel fabrication will be completed by BCIT Ironwork students at the Burnaby Campus. 
The benches and tables will be built with students from Britannia Secondary School, who will be employed and given training in laser etching/cutting.
The team is working with public artist Jordan Bent to complete a laser etched art piece on the planter boxes of the parklet.
Laser etching will be completed by Derek Gaw, based out of the Vancouver Community Laboratory.
Parklet construction will be recorded in stop-motion by local photographer Eric Scott, and played in real-time at Prado Café. 
The project will be cleaned and loved by Prado Cafe, and enjoyed by YOU! 
Parklet Plan Drawing
VIVA Vancouver suggests that parklets cost between $10,000 and 20,000 to design and build. The Commercial Drive Parklet team has sought to strike a balance between design/material quality, collaboration costs, and total expenses to deliver a total budget of $14,000. Working with local artists, entrepreneurs, and youth can cost extra money - but we believe it's worth it!
The project has received $5000 in funding from the owner of Prado Cafe, as well as $1000 from the Awesome Foundation. 
Please be aware that VIVA requires local businesses to sponsor and maintain parklets. As part of Prado's contributions to the parklet, they must pay $1500 in up-front fees, plus a yearly fee towards the City.
The parklet has broad support by patrons of Prado café, as well as adjacent business owners, the Grandview Woodlands Community Policing Centre, Britannia Secondary School, and the Commercial Drive BIA. If you're still curious, check out some past work by the collaborators:
Julien's Park-a-Park project
Jordan's Whispers Project

Thank you to Brinkman Urban Restoration for donating soil and plants towards the project. Please share our campaign with your friends!

campaign.story:
Aurora is an interactive Burning Man LED sculpture by Bay Area Artist Charles Gadeken. This enormous and brilliant work of art will live for one year in front of Palo Alto City Hall. Our installation date is November 16, 2013. We are raising money to make improvements, customize, weatherize, and install Aurora, as well as develop a mobile interface for visitors to interact with Aurora.
Aurora is a complex and robust piece of electronic art. She is 30 feet tall and has over 40,000 LEDS, and 4,200 shimmering, hand-beaten leaves.  Originally made for Burning Man, now Aurora is coming to Palo Alto City Hall Plaza.
Palo Alto is reclaiming the old-time Town Square with high-tech flare. Aurora is a 21st Century “El Palo Alto” (the namesake tree for this city). She creates a place for people of all ages and all walks of life to gather, meet, talk and break down barriers through her unique combination of technology with sustainable energy and public art. The application of technology makes Aurora interactive and accessible. Anyone with a finger and web access can “paint” in light using Aurora as their canvas. High-efficiency LED lights powered by zero-emission electricity compel onlookers to consider their own energy and water consumption.
Aurora at Burning Man (Photo by Camaelon)
How Two Kids Brought Aurora to Palo Alto
Two Palo Alto kids, Sam and Julia, saw a photo of Aurora at Burning Man and decided it would be really cool to have Aurora in Palo Alto. They wanted to learn just what it takes to get a public art project from concept to achievement. They jumped in with both feet!
First, they got Palo Alto citizens to sign a petition for the project. Then they went to a meeting of the Palo Arts Commission. The Art Commission agreed to allow Sam and Julia to present the project at one of their public meetings. Sam and Julia stood up at the microphone in front of the dais before the Art Commissioners and staff and presented Aurora. The Palo Alto Art Commission unanimously approved Aurora pending fundraising and engineering validation.  Sam observed shortly afterwards, “It took us one year and we got half a ‘Yes’!”
Undaunted, Sam and Julia gathered support throughout the Palo Alto community. They created a group of Aurora Kids - leaf makers and shakers, public speakers, and fundraisers - who made many of the leafs that you see on Aurora.
Julia making a leaf at The Maker Faire (photo by Jason Chinn)
Now, the Aurora Kids have raised some of the money required, but not enough. Meanwhile, the rest of the departments at the City of Palo Alto have added their support by issuing building and planning permits, special event permits, traffic closure plans, engineering sign-offs, landscaping and electrical work, and much more.
Supporters
The City of Palo Alto supports this project.  The mayor of Palo Alto supports this Aurora. The Palo Alto Downtown Business Association supports this project. The  Black Rock Arts Foundation supports this project. Now it is YOUR turn to support Aurora!
Aurora is in the home stretch. Sam, Julia and the Aurora Kids have now gained skills, experience and confidence that they can be part of the civic process. They have communicated personally with Larry Harvey and the Palo Alto Mayor. They have made leafs, recruited supporters, spoken before large groups, presented to businesses and learned how to engage in the political process for positive change.
Please consider supporting Sam, Julia and all the Aurora Kids so that they can fundraise the amount needed for installing and maintaining LED interactive art in Palo Alto, the heart of Silicon Valley.
About the Artist
Charles Gadeken makes monumental artwork that thus far has incorporated mixed metals, interactive and kinetic elements, and special effects such as fire, light, and electricity. His artistic practice seeks to realize the potential for unexpected magic and serendipity in everyday life. His work instills a sense of play in the environment, remaking the mundane into magical items existing as real life portals into our imaginations.
Aurora was made by Charles and a community of forty artists, engineers, metalworkers and volunteers. 
http://www.charlesgadeken.com
Why you should support us
Aurora is a stunning and spectacular interactive LED installation that is just really really cool. Aurora will illuminate the area around City Hall, and invigorate the civic heart of Palo Alto.
Kickstarter Goals and Budget
Our kickstarter campaign is set to be funded at $35,000. However, our goal is actually $50,000. We will set Kickstarter "stretch" goals as we get closer. Anything raised beyond this will go toward enhancements to Aurora’s interactivity such as a touch-screen kiosk and upgrades to her LED’s and electronics and power grid.
Why do we need $50,000?
The biggest question we get tasked is why we need so much money to install a piece of art. The answer is: big art costs big money. Your money will go towards adapting the structure to the more demanding requirements for public display over a long period of time.
We are rebuilding from scratch the LED wiring and electronics to make them weatherproof and more robust so that she’ll operate continuously and unattended no matter what happens throughout the year. We are making Aurora interactive and aware of her surroundings through a mobile interface.
We are customizing her to fit inside the former fountain turned planter on the plaza and upgrading the structure to meet wind and seismic building codes. We are proud to say the engineering is complete and is approved by Palo Alto’s Building, Planning and Public Works Departments. This has been tough, we only make it look easy.
Budget
Structural Rebuild (new i-beam base & certified welds): $10,000
Re-Painting and : $6,000 LED new wiring harness & connectors: $3,000 
Installation (5 person crew, 4 days each): $5,000
Tear Down (In one year: 5 person crew, 4 days each): $5,000
New computer brain, power supplies and waterproof enclosures: $4,000
Landscaping and irrigation for native grasses around Aurora’s base: $3,000
Payroll:  $25,000
TOTAL: $55,000 (not including kickstarter costs)
Why hasn’t the City funded this project?
When the Palo Alto Arts Commission first approved this project, they made it clear that we would have to raise the money on our own. However, the entire City of Palo Alto has bent over backwards to help us. The City has removed many barriers to this installation that could have cost thousands of dollars. The City has waived all permit costs, upgraded the power at City Hall to support Aurora's needs and facilitated the permitting process.
Aurora at Dusk (photo by Dust to Ashes)
We thank all City officials for their energy, commitment and dedication to getting this project to its November 16th install date. Without the support of the City we would not be able to commit to this install date.
Thank You!
Thank you for watching our kickstarter campaign. We think this is a great project for you to support. Help us bring Burning Man art to the best city in California. Help Sam, Julia and the Aurora Kids make an IMPACT in their city and make their dreams come true.
With love, 
The Aurora Palo Alto Team

campaign.story:
Michron
Michron is a device that plugs into your camera and allows you to take timelapses. This kind of device is called an intervalometer. Michron is special because it has no buttons or screens; instead the user interface is the Michron App on your smart phone (Android or iPhone). 
Once you’ve created your settings in the app, upload them by plugging your phone into Michron with the programming cable. After you have uploaded your settings, you can disconnect your phone. Michron will perform completely on its own. Once Michron is plugged into the trigger port, it will tell your camera to take photos according to your settings. And don't worry, Michron's battery has a life of over 2500 hours, meaning you will probably never have to replace it (and if you do, it's easy to replace).
What is a timelapse?
A timelapse is a collection of photos taken over a period of time that are then compiled together to create a video that expresses time in a way not normally seen. Timelapse photography gives you the freedom to visualize the passage of time as you want, allowing for infinite creativity. To see one of the many videos that got us inspired by timelapse photography, check out http://vimeo.com/23237102
Which cameras does Michron work with?
Michron works with any camera with an external trigger port. This includes almost all DSLR's and a growing number of point and shoot cameras (to see the full list, please see our FAQ). We will confirm your camera make and model when we send out our survey to ensure that you get the appropriate cable for your camera. 
How do you turn the photos into a video?
Michron tells your camera to take photos at the interval you designate in the app. After you are done collecting the photos you can open them into any one of a handful of free or purchased programs (Timelapse Assembler, Lightroom, etc) which will quickly turn your photos into the final video. Although it is straightforward, we will also provide a short video showing how to use these programs as part of our manual.
Tutorials:
We will provide a few tutorial videos to help you get started taking timelapses. In these videos we will show you how to use each individual feature of Michron as well as share some tips and tricks that we have learned from our experience on how to take better timelapses.
Made In America
Michron will be manufactured and assembled in the United States, although certain items such as accessory cables and electronics components may be sourced through non-domestic channels since many of these items are not made in the United States. 
Features
Michron is programmed by your Android or iOS device (If you don't have one of these, check our out FAQ for some more information), allowing us to program in some cool features not feasible on a device sporting an LCD screen and a few buttons. 
AutoTimelapse™:
If you are completely new to photography or timelapse this optional feature is for you! Put your camera in Landscape mode (or Portrait, Night Scene, etc) and pick a pre-made setting on Michron: People, Clouds, Landscape, Cityscape, Stars. From these presets, Michron creates all the settings for you and works with your camera as it shoots in Auto.
Intervalometers typically require the photographer to shoot in Manual (meaning the user adjusts the camera exposure) but many people do not know how to do this. AutoTimelapse fixes this problem and makes timelapse accessible to all photographers.
Interval Ramping:
Interval ramping allows users to change the interval between shots during the timelapse. For example: most timelapses are taken at a fixed interval, such as one photo every 30 seconds for 2 hours. With interval ramping, you can start at 30 seconds, then speed up to every 5 seconds at the one hour mark, and then slow down again to every 60 seconds for the last 15 minutes of the timelapse. (See the clock shot in the video!)
Bulb Ramping:
Bulb ramping allows you to make smooth light transitions. Michron will continually adjust the shutter speed of the camera according to your settings. This feature is extremely useful in shots with dynamic lighting such as a sunset or sunrise. Michron is designed to work with or without a PC Sync cable. 
HDR Bracketing*:
This feature allows you to make multiple exposures for every photo you take in your timelapse. Instead of taking a single photo after each interval, your camera takes a set of three closely-spaced photos, each at a different exposure. You can then later edit each batch of three photos into an HDR image in your photo software of choice and compile an HDR timelapse.
*HDR stands for High Dynamic Range, meaning an image that has very dark parts and very bright parts. Bracketing means taking multiple photos of the same image at different exposures.
External Trigger:
This is an awesome little feature. For new photographers, this is something you want to have. For experienced photographers, it will be nice to know you have an extra one in your camera bag. This feature allows you to take a photo on your camera by triggering it through your phone, from a distance of about two feet. This eliminates camera shake, allowing you to take sharper images (no blur!).
Portable:
We've made Michron as small as possible, so that you can take it wherever you go without even realizing it's there. And, since it's designed to sit in your camera's hotshoe, it will stay out of the way when in use. 
Stretch Goal!
 2500 Backers- Photo Booth:
This feature will allow you to take easy group or self portraits, even when your camera is far away from what is being shot. Many cameras already have a self timer feature for taking photos such as this, but typically the delay is only for 10 seconds and does not let you control how many photos are taken. This was a big complaint of Steve’s after spending 20 minutes trying to get a group shot on top of a rock (there was lots of running involved) so we’d love to add it into Michron.
Goofy Poses Optional
With the Photobooth feature, you can set how long the delay is, how many photos to take, and how long between each photo. That way, you have plenty of time to get into position and take all the photos you want. Basically, Photobooth is everything you wish you camera self timer could do.
Not just for timelapse:
Michron was designed to be as flexible as possible because we know what creative people can do with a tool like this. Because Michron is, at the heart of it, taking numerous still photos at a set interval, it can be used for a few other things as well, although we are sure you will think of many more:
Easily take multiple photos for self portrait and group shots
Stop motion and claymation
Photo stitching
The Project:
We have been working on this project for several months now and are ready to launch. We have finished our R&D and have a refined prototype that is sourced and ready to manufacture. However, manufacturing and delivering a physical product is not cheap, which is why we are really excited to be here on Kickstarter asking for your support. This money will fund the first production run of the Michron. The money raised here will go to the following: 
Up-front, one-time manufacturing costs
Per unit manufacturing cost and accessory cables
Shipping 
The App:
The Michron App is a licensed and adapted version of the Android- and iPhone-compatible smartphone interface originally developed by Alpine Labs for Radian. The app is free and will be available for download through the Google and Apple app stores. The app is compatible with all Android devices newer than 2.3 (aka Gingerbread), and all iOS devices running iOS 5.0 or newer.
How Michron Got Here
Michron has come a long way from Steve's first sketches drawn in the back of a taxi in China. 
Utilizing 3D printing, both on a home printer and using commercial services, we were able to rapidly iterate the mechanical design, to create a package that is both compact and functional. In addition, we have worked extensively with the company that will be producing our injection molded parts to ensure that the Michron enclosure can be made to our specifications.
In addition to the mechanical design and iteration (the visible parts) significant work went into miniaturizing the printed circuit boards to help us shrink the housing even further. Fortunately, the first PCB we designed worked great, and shrinking it down went smoothly as well. We've since moved the ports around to improve fit for our V3 boards, which are in the mail. 
Once the printed circuit boards were working happily, we had to nail down the firmware (the code that runs on Michron) so that it plays well with the smartphone app, and could execute all of our advanced features. Ultimately the Michron to phone interface went smoothly, thanks to Steve's past experience with Radian, but it still took a good deal of time, and we are still adding and altering some small features as we continue to get feedback from our users. 
Timeline
As soon as we reach our funding goal we will order the molds for Michron's housing (this is one of the slowest steps in manufacturing). This will allow us to start a major part of the manufacturing process before the campaign ends, enabling us to deliver the Michron to you even faster. Barring any unforeseen manufacturing issues (explained under "Risks and Challenges"), we expect to package and ship your Michron in March.
Accountability
We will email our backers with regular updates regarding the production process as well as provide behind the scenes footage from the manufacturing floor. We promise to run a transparent campaign and to keep our backers up-to-date and informed.

As with all projects, there is the possibility for issues outside of our control to appear. While we have done everything in our power to ensure that Michron is completely ready to go, there is always the chance of delays in manufacturing due to the following:

- Manufacturing the housings : We have confirmed with our molder that the design can be easily manufactured, but it is possible that it takes longer than expected to produce parts that meet our quality standards.

3. Polished and hand blasted for 3 days;
4. Carving stamps for 3 days;
5. Testing, assembling and packaging for 2days;
6. Checking information and delivery for 2days.
We may need 1 week more for production if there are more than 600 supports of Titanium roller pens. 
We will take the lowest risk on condition that the quality is guaranteed.

We choose to produce the roller pens in China where there are world-class precise fabricating machines and engineers.
The pens in the picture are the newest samples and the final products may have some minor differences to make a perfect appearance.
We devote all we energy and money to the pens designing and producing and economize in packages.

iPad Mini & the Gumstick
                    The Flexible stand
Pocket sized... 
 Travels as easily as you do.
Simplistic in both design and function, the Gumstick™ bends and shapes to fit all Smartphones & mini tablets. 
The stand has been designed around everyday situations and can be used for holding phones in many different positions, allowing for viewing in both landscape and portrait modes.  Lightweight, strong, compact and highly portable the Gumstick™ can easily be tucked into a bag or pocket, making it the perfect accessory to your busy on the go lifestyle.
At the gym.
Breffo Gumstick Smartphone Stand
Perfect for Facetime, Skype & Video calls
Gumstick™ Stand
Perfect for video calls, the Gumstick™ can be pulled from a pocket or bag and quickly molded into the ideal position for hosting an on the go conference call.
Gumstick Stand Kickstarter Movie
Movies anywhere and everywhere you are!  Simply mold the Gumstick™ into your shape of choice.  Presto!  The ability to position the phone at any desired angle!  The perfect solution for the kids+movie+restaurant table combo!
Bend into position...
The Gumstick™ is perfect in weight and balance, its flat tactile shape feels great in your hand yet it yearns to be molded.  Once you start bending the product you’ll just want to keep doing it!  
Initial Design: A member of the Breffo team gets down to designing the perfect Smartphone stand for at home or on the move.  Every position is considered, every phone size on the market taken into account, the process is very detailed and very exciting!
Core Product Features
Beautiful in design and form.
Extremely portable for everyday use and travel
Lightweight and strong
Fully flexible
Compatible with all smartphones 
Bends flat for easy storage
View at any angle in any position in any location
Designed and manufactured exclusively in the UK
The flexibility and many ways to position the Gumstick™ allow creation to take place and we love creation! Following recipes in the kitchen becomes a piece of cake!
Gumstick & Blackberry - Bedside Clock
Who’s a smart stand then! Use your Gumstick™ in different a multitude of scenarios. From a shape to sit on a desk to a shape to hang from a shelf, there are no restrictions on how the GumStick™ can be used.  Clean and simple bedside stand?  No Problem!
New Pledge level for custom laser etching! 
Laser Etching
You can know customize the Gumstick stand and have your name, company or website laser etched directly on to it exclusive to Kickstarter! Any pledges over $23 automatically get this as an free upgrade option. For more information take a look at the FAQ at the bottom of the page.
Colors, colors, beautiful colors! We will be launching the Gumstick production in the following colors...
The range of colors we will be producing!
Who We Are
Breffo is a lifestyle and design manufacturing company with offices in the UK and Portland, OR.  We're passionate about creating products combining both uniqueness and impeccable design with quality and craftsmanship.  
Development and Manufacturing
Design - Our design team have been working on the development of this product for the last 6 months.  From the form and function of the Gumstick™ to the finish and colors, the team have taken all aspects of the design into consideration before prototyping the product.
Manufacturing - We have the all the plant machinery in place and have an established relationship with the factory who will be manufacturing the final production run. 
Process - The team has spent a great deal of time optimizing the manufacturing process and we have now have our production cycle and timelines confirmed.
Costs - With our background in mobile stands we have been able to negotiate the best costs with our production partners, ensuring that the Gumstick™ can be offered to end consumers at an accessible retail. You get a lot of functionality for your buck!
Working Prototypes - We have our initial prototypes approved and have finalized the design.  Once we meet our funding requirement we will be in a position to finish the final tooling on the molds and be prepped and ready to start production.
We are looking to continuously grow our product range and firmly establish ourselves as a lifestyle brand with in the consumer electronics accessories market and beyond. 
Our inspirational outlook and cool, clean, modern brand identity represent our approach to business. We are collectively forward, futuristic thinkers. 
The team at work in the UK office
Meet the Team!
Patrick Mathews - Founder and Resident Head Honcho              
Patrick spent many years working in a management role within investment banking and IT.  As we all know 'management role' is a very fluffy term and really means that Patrick was not really very important at all in his last job.  He just thought he was. Fortunately; however, he has decided to follow his passion for all things tech and beautiful looking and founded Breffo in 2009.  Being the CEO, Patrick now holds a very senior role yet he's confident that he is still generally just 'not very important at all'. Consistency is key!  A creative at heart and a true entrepreneur he lives day to day in the thick of creativity and thank goodness for it, as the output yields some pretty cool stuff!  Patrick now lives in the UK with his family and very happily 'acts' like he manages the UK, European and International operations', though we all know he just makes a lot of coffee!  As seems to be the case with all entrepreneurs, outside of work Patrick wonders if there actually is an 'outside of work' life. 
Chris Facey - Vice President of Product Development 
Chris is an experienced product designer with a wealth of knowledge in designing and manufacturing consumer products. In 2006 Chris teamed up with Daniel Ashman (now Vice President of Design at Breffo) to start a product design consultancy, together they successfully ran the business for over 6 years. As a consultant Chris worked on design development for a number of large global organizations including Sharp, Microsoft and Belkin.  In 2009 the consultancy was approached by Patrick to help develop his idea, the Spiderpodium and later the Spiderpodium Tablet. Three years later in 2012 Chris left the consultancy to work for Breffo full time as Product Development Vice President and oversee's all global production for the brand.  Chris lives in Cardiff with his wife Siobhan. Outside of work he enjoys playing golf (although not very well), going for the occasional run (very occasional) and enjoying a nice cold beer in the local pub after a hard day's work (not that he works very hard...).
Daniel Ashman - Vice President of Design
Prior to Breffo Dan managed a product design consultancy start up with fellow colleague Chris Facey.  The team quickly established themselves as a serious players in the industry winning major global clients and a number of product design and business awards.  Dan officially joined Breffo in 2012 overseeing all design as well as managing business development in Europe, Scandinavia and Asia. Dan has been known to take extremely bad medical advice from his US Breffo colleagues when not feeling well.  An example of which would be to swallow a dissolvable vitamin C tablet while sitting on top of the Stratosphere roller coaster in Las Vegas (this all transpired during CES 2012) which resulted in a foamy gas bursting out of his nose uncontrollably (to everyone else's amusement). Dan lives with his girlfriend Lauren in Cardiff who is very understanding considering Dan is a workaholic and eats, sleeps and breathes Breffo!
Sara McMahon - General Merchandise Manager North America     
Sara has worked in a licensee capacity with global brands such as Levi's, Docker’s and Nautica and also has national retail experience as the Head of Buying for Gift and Hard Goods with retailer Papyrus.  She met Patrick in 2000 when they and their partners (now spouses) were living it up in San Francisco, CA (where Patrick was pretending to be important in Finance). Fast forward 2 weddings, 4 kids (between them), a transatlantic move (him) and 13 years of friendship - Patrick coerced Sara into leaving her corporate career for the excitement of a start up!  She joined the Breffo team in 2011 and was instrumental in the opening of the US headquarters and is responsible for all marketing and distribution of Breffo products within North America. When she's not spending time with her family you can catch her at the yoga studio or indulging in her love of exorbitantly priced designer footwear.  She is also actively involved in volunteering within the Portland metro area with organizations such as Living Yoga and the Junior League.                
How We Get it Done
Although still at start up level, we have successfully launched and distributed several other products prior to the Gumstick™.  Our most success being the Spiderpodium Original  which has won numerous design awards including the CES Design and Engineering Award in 2011.
We manufacture our products exclusively in the United Kingdom (UK), renowned for their quality manufacturing.  Our UK base manages all facets of development and production allowing for better quality assurance as we regularly conduct inline quality inspection to guarantee we are providing the highest level of product to our customers. Our Portland, OR based office oversees North American distribution and will serve as the hub for our Kickstarter project.  The Portland team is responsible for all facets of the campaign and will be the lead team managing the distribution and shipping of all Kickstarter rewards.
How Your Pledges Will Help
Despite rapid growth, like all start ups we are experiencing the growing pains of taking our brand and company to the next level, bringing products to market is one of the most difficult challenges a new company faces.  Here are some of the areas your pledges will support.  Helping to make this concept reality.
Tooling & Development - Fundamental to the project and one of the largest early stage expenses.
Production - The actual production cost of the product, materials, running the tools and manufacturing the final product.
Quality Assurance & Packaging - Presenting long lasting quality products to customers in a beautiful way. Also, they need to come wrapped in something.
Thank You!!
We are excited to have the opportunity to use Kickstarter as a platform to launch the Gumstick™ and hope you will support us in reaching our fundraising goal.  From all of the team here at Breffo, we would like to sincerely thank you in advance for your very generous support!
